skill.name: extract-transcripts
skill.description: Extract readable transcripts from Claude Code and Codex CLI session JSONL files
skill.summary: Extract readable transcripts from Claude Code and Codex CLI session JSONL files
skill.author: 0xBigBoss

security_audit.summary: Pure Python file processing utility with no network access, no code execution capabilities, and no credential or sensitive data exposure. All operations are confined to user-specified JSONL session files and local output.

content.user_title: Convert session logs to readable transcripts
content.value_statement: Claude Code and Codex CLI store conversation history as JSONL files that are difficult to read manually. This skill extracts those sessions into clean markdown format with metadata, timestamps, and optional tool call details.
actual_capabilities: Extract Claude Code session JSONL files to readable markdown
Extract Codex CLI session rollout files to readable format
Index and search across multiple sessions using DuckDB
Filter sessions by date, project, or keyword
Include or exclude tool calls and thinking blocks from output
Batch process all sessions in a directory
limitations: Requires Python 3 with optional DuckDB dependency for indexing
Does not modify or delete original session files
Only reads from local session paths (no remote fetch)
Does not extract token usage or cost data

use_cases.title: Session Review
use_cases.description: Review past AI assistance sessions to recall decisions, context, or code patterns

use_cases.title: Generate Guides
use_cases.description: Convert session logs into tutorial content or process documentation

use_cases.title: Audit Usage
use_cases.description: Search across team sessions to identify patterns or verify implementation approaches

prompt_templates.title: Extract a session
prompt_templates.scenario: Convert Claude Code session to markdown
prompt_templates.prompt: Extract the Claude Code session at ~/.claude/projects/myproject/abc123.jsonl to a readable transcript

prompt_templates.title: Search sessions
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me all Claude Code sessions from the last week that mention authentication

prompt_templates.title: Batch export
prompt_templates.scenario: Convert all sessions in a project
prompt_templates.prompt: Extract all Claude Code sessions from ~/projects/api-server into markdown files

output_examples.input: Extract the Claude Code session at ~/.claude/projects/myproject/session.jsonl
output: Help me implement user authentication with JWT tokens...
I'll help you set up JWT authentication. Let me first check your project structure.

best_practices: Use --summary flag for quick session overviews when you only need metadata
Use --skip-empty to filter out warmup-only test sessions during batch processing
Run transcript index to enable full-text search across your session history
anti_patterns: Do not rely on session IDs as unique identifiers - subagents can share IDs
Do not expect token counts or cost data - this information is not stored in session files
Do not modify original JSONL files - the extractor only reads from them

faq.question: What platforms are supported?
faq.answer: Claude Code CLI, Codex CLI, and Claude Code desktop app on macOS, Linux, and Windows.

faq.question: How large can sessions be?
faq.answer: Sessions are limited by your disk storage. Individual transcript output truncates messages over 2000 characters.

faq.question: Can I integrate with other tools?
faq.answer: Yes, scripts output to stdout or files. Pipe output to other tools or redirect to files for integration.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: All processing is local. No data is sent anywhere. The index stores transcripts in a local DuckDB database.

faq.question: Why are sessions not appearing?
faq.answer: Check that session paths exist. Use --path to specify custom directories. Run index --full to force re-scan.

faq.question: How is this different from native exports?
faq.answer: Native exports provide raw JSONL. This tool formats conversations as readable markdown with metadata and context.
